sections.title: Passage 1 – The development of the London underground railway

questions.label: Q1
questions.prompt: The ________ of London increased rapidly between 1800 and 1850.

questions.label: Q2
questions.prompt: Building the railway would make it possible to move people to better housing in the ________.

questions.label: Q3
questions.prompt: A number of ________ agreed with Pearson’s idea.

questions.label: Q4
questions.prompt: The company initially had problems getting the ________ needed for the project.

questions.label: Q5
questions.prompt: Negative articles about the project appeared in the ________.

questions.label: Q6
questions.prompt: With the completion of the brick arch, the tunnel was covered with ________.

questions.label: Q7
questions.prompt: Other countries had built underground railways before the Metropolitan line opened.

questions.label: Q8
questions.prompt: More people than predicted travelled on the Metropolitan line on the first day.

questions.label: Q9
questions.prompt: The use of ventilation shafts failed to prevent pollution in the tunnels.

questions.label: Q10
questions.prompt: A different approach from the ‘cut and cover’ technique was required in London’s central area.

questions.label: Q11
questions.prompt: The windows on City & South London trains were at eye level.

questions.label: Q12
questions.prompt: The City & South London Railway was a financial success.

questions.label: Q13
questions.prompt: Trains on the ‘Tuppenny Tube’ nearly always ran on time.

sections.title: Passage 2 – Stadiums: past, present and future

questions.label: Q14
questions.hint: Which section contains the following information? Write the correct letter, A–G.
questions.prompt: a mention of negative attitudes towards stadium building projects

questions.label: Q15
questions.hint: Which section contains the following information? Write the correct letter, A–G.
questions.prompt: figures demonstrating the environmental benefits of a certain stadium

questions.label: Q16
questions.hint: Which section contains the following information? Write the correct letter, A–G.
questions.prompt: examples of the wide range of facilities available at some new stadiums

questions.label: Q17
questions.hint: Which section contains the following information? Write the correct letter, A–G.
questions.prompt: reference to the disadvantages of the stadiums built during a certain era

questions.label: Q18
questions.prompt: The amphitheatre of Arles, for example, was converted first into a ________.

questions.label: Q19
questions.prompt: The amphitheatre of Arles was finally converted into an arena where spectators could watch ________.

questions.label: Q20
questions.prompt: The arena in Verona is famous today as a venue where ________ is performed.

questions.label: Q21
questions.prompt: The site of Lucca’s amphitheatre has also been used for many purposes over the centuries, including the storage of ________.

questions.label: Q22
questions.prompt: The site of Lucca’s amphitheatre is now a market square with ________ and homes incorporated into the remains of the Roman amphitheatre.

questions.label: Q23
questions.hint: Choose TWO letters, A–E. (Select one of the two correct answers.)
questions.prompt: When comparing twentieth-century stadiums to ancient amphitheatres in Section D, which TWO negative features does the writer mention?

options.text: They are in less convenient locations.
They are made of less durable materials.

questions.label: Q24
questions.hint: Choose TWO letters, A–E. (Select the other correct answer.)
questions.prompt: When comparing twentieth-century stadiums to ancient amphitheatres in Section D, which TWO negative features does the writer mention?

options.text: They are in less convenient locations.
They are made of less durable materials.

questions.label: Q25
questions.hint: Choose TWO letters, A–E. (Select one of the two correct answers.)
questions.prompt: Which TWO advantages of modern stadium design does the writer mention?

options.text: offering improved amenities for the enjoyment of sports events
bringing community life back into the city environment
facilitating research into solar and wind energy solutions
enabling local residents to reduce their consumption of electricity
providing a suitable site for the installation of renewable power generators

questions.label: Q26
questions.hint: Choose TWO letters, A–E. (Select the other correct answer.)
questions.prompt: Which TWO advantages of modern stadium design does the writer mention?

options.text: offering improved amenities for the enjoyment of sports events
bringing community life back into the city environment
facilitating research into solar and wind energy solutions
enabling local residents to reduce their consumption of electricity
providing a suitable site for the installation of renewable power generators

questions.label: Q27
questions.prompt: Charles II then formed a ________ with the Scots.

questions.label: Q28
questions.prompt: In order to become King of Scots, he abandoned an important ________ that was held by his father and had contributed to his father’s death.

questions.label: Q29
questions.prompt: The battle led to a ________ for the Parliamentarians.

questions.label: Q30
questions.prompt: A ________ was offered for Charles’s capture.

questions.label: Q31
questions.prompt: After six weeks spent in hiding, he eventually managed to reach the ________ of continental Europe.

questions.label: Q32
questions.prompt: Charles chose Pepys for the task because he considered him to be trustworthy.

questions.label: Q33
questions.prompt: Charles’s personal recollection of the escape lacked sufficient detail.

questions.label: Q34
questions.prompt: Charles indicated to Pepys that he had planned his escape before the battle.

questions.label: Q35
questions.prompt: The inclusion of Charles’s account is a positive aspect of the book.

questions.label: Q36
questions.hint: Choose the correct letter, A, B, C or D.
questions.prompt: What is the reviewer’s main purpose in the first paragraph?

options.text: to describe what happened during the Battle of Worcester
to give an account of the circumstances leading to Charles II’s escape
to provide details of the Parliamentarians’ political views
to compare Charles II’s beliefs with those of his father

questions.label: Q37
questions.hint: Choose the correct letter, A, B, C or D.
questions.prompt: Why does the reviewer include examples of the fugitives’ behaviour in the third paragraph?

options.text: to explain how close Charles II came to losing his life
to suggest that Charles II’s supporters were badly prepared
to illustrate how the events of the six weeks are brought to life
to argue that certain aspects are not as well known as they should be

questions.label: Q38
questions.hint: Choose the correct letter, A, B, C or D.
questions.prompt: What point does the reviewer make about Charles II in the fourth paragraph?

options.text: He chose to celebrate what was essentially a defeat.
He misunderstood the motives of his opponents.
He aimed to restore people’s faith in the monarchy.
He was driven by a desire to be popular.

questions.label: Q39
questions.hint: Choose the correct letter, A, B, C or D.
questions.prompt: What does the reviewer say about Charles Spencer in the fifth paragraph?

options.text: His decision to write the book comes as a surprise.
He takes an unbiased approach to the subject matter.
His descriptions of events would be better if they included more detail.
He chooses language that is suitable for a twenty-first-century audience.

questions.label: Q40
questions.hint: Choose the correct letter, A, B, C or D.
questions.prompt: When the reviewer says the book ‘doesn’t quite hit the mark’, she is making the point that

options.text: it overlooks the impact of events on ordinary people.
it lacks an analysis of prevalent views on monarchy.
it omits any references to the deceit practised by Charles II during his time in hiding.
it fails to address whether Charles II’s experiences had a lasting influence on him.
